<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_close(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				struct linux_device *ldev)
{
	(void)lbus;
	unsigned int i;

	for (i = 0; i < ldev->device.num_regions; i++) {
		metal_unmap(ldev->device.regions[i].virt,
			    ldev->device.regions[i].size);
	}
	if (ldev->override) {
		sysfs_write_attribute(ldev->override, "", 1);
		ldev->override = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->sdev) {
		sysfs_close_device(ldev->sdev);
		ldev->sdev = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->fd >= 0) {
		close(ldev->fd);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
	metal_unmap(ldev->device.regions[i].virt,
			    ldev->device.regions[i].size);
	}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown code: the for loop has a single loop counter (i) initialized in the first clause, the loop condition uses i and ldev->device.num_regions (which is not shown being modified in the loop body), and the third clause (i++) modifies only the loop counter. Therefore Rule 14.2 is not violated here, provided that metal_unmap (or any function it calls) does not modify ldev->device.num_regions or i. A specific violation scenario would be if metal_unmap (directly or indirectly) modified ldev->device.num_regions (or any other object used in the loop condition) or modified the loop counter; in that case the second/third clauses would be using objects that are modified by the loop body and Rule 14.2 would be violated.
